data.title: Novels by E. E. Doc Smith (Study Guide) - The Skylark of Space, Spacehounds of Ipc, Imperial Stars, Subspace Explorers, Skylark Three (Paperback)
data.meta_description: This is nonfiction commentary. Purchase includes a free trial membership in the publisher's book club where you can select from more than a million books without charge. Chapters: The Skylark of Space, Spacehounds of Ipc, Imperial Stars, Subspace Explorers, Skylark Three, Skylark of Valeron, the History of Civilization, Skylark Duquesne, Subspace Encounter. Source: Wikipedia. Free updates online. Not illustrated. Excerpt: The Skylark of Space is one of the earliest novels of interstellar travel. Originally serialized in 1928 in the magazine Amazing Stories, it was first published in book form in 1946 by The Buffalo Book Co. It was written between 1915 and 1921 by Edward E. "Doc" Smith while working on his doctorate and later as a food chemist, and Lee Hawkins Garby, the wife of his college classmate and later neighbor Carl Garby. The Skylark of Space is often categorized as the first literary space opera (in the complimentary sense), complete with protagonists perfect in mind, body, and spirit, who fight against villains of absolute evil. The Skylark series has been in and out of print ever since its first publication, in both hardback and paperback editions, and is considered a classic of pulp science fiction. Frederik Pohl says of the book, "With the exception of the works of H. G. Wells, possibly those of Jules Verne and almost no other writer it has inspired more imitators and done more to change the nature of all the science fiction written after it than almost any other single work." For more details of the publication history of the story and series, see E. E. Smith. The Skylark of Space is the first book in the Skylark series and pits the hero, Dick Seaton, against Marc DuQuesne ( pronounced "Du Kane"). The story is not only in the whiz-bang technology, although there is a lot of that, but in the contrast in characters of Seaton and DuQuesne.
